section.title: Implied Forward Rates and Spot Rates
section.p: Given a yield curve, the spot rates imply forward rates -- otherwise there would be an arbitrage opportunity. Similarly, given a set of forward rates, there is an implied yield curve. In this activity, we will figure learn how to figure these out.
For ease of notation, we will write s_k in place of s_0(k) in this activity.

introduction.p: Suppose we know the yield curve s_k for k = 1, \ldots, n and we want to find \iota_0(n-1,n). The following approach (whether with or without the timeline) is called "making an arbitrage argument."

task.p: Make an interest rate timeline which shows two paths from 0 to n: one using s_n and another using s_{n-1} and \iota_0(n-1,n).

Assume that an investor can borrow and lend along both paths without transaction costs. Show that if the two paths you plotted do not result in the same value at time n, arbitrage is possible. Address both the case where the path using s_{n-1} and \iota_0(n-1) results in a larger amount and the case where that path results in a smaller amount.
Assuming there is no arbitrage, write down an equation that must hold concerning the two paths, and solve your equation for \iota_0(n-1,n). This is called the implied forward rate.
